iati-activity.title: Phalombe Teacher Training College Construction
iati-activity.description: To improve quality of education in Malawi by providing a fully functional teacher training college in Phalombe District with capacity to train 300 students every year. This will provide more qualified teachers (especially female teachers) in rural areas (which comprise 80% of Malawi population) contributing towards addressing the shortage of teachers. This contributes to MDG 2 and 3 by reducing the Pupil:Teacher Ratio currently at 74:1 and needs about 26,000 more teachers to reach a target of 60:1 by 2013.

contact-info.mailing-address: Public Enquiry Point, Abercrombie House, Eaglesham Road, East Kilbride, Glasgow G75 8EA

iati-activity.title: Health Sector Support Programme
iati-activity.description: To improve utilisation of quality, effective essential health services especially for the poor and deliver the following outputs through Essential Health Package (EHP): 4.3 million underfive treated for pneumonia; 63,000 patients treated for TB; 2.3 million deliveries by skilled health worker; 363,000 additional family planning users; 416,000 adults on ART in 2015; 2.4 million children fully immunised; 25 million children treated for malaria and 10 million bednets distributed

iati-activity.title: Support to Family Planning
iati-activity.description: To increase the coverage and use of effective family planning in Malawi by increasing access to family planning services to the rural, poor and young women; and procurement of family planning commodities. This will benefit 3.0 million people and increase the national contraceptive rate (CPR) from 42% to 55% by 2018. This contributes towards our MDG by reducing Maternal mortality.

iati-activity.title: HIV Prevention Project
iati-activity.description: To support the government of Malawi's 5 year HIV/AIDS Strategy (2011-2016) by scaling up prevention of mother to child transmission (PMTCT) with a special focus on male involvement, increasing HIV Counselling & Testing(HTC) and increasing availability and access to condoms especially among discordant couples. These interventions will avert 5932 new HIV infections by 2016;163800 couples will take HIV Testing and Counselling by 2016 and an extra 1,031,885 clients will test for HIV and receive counselling by 2016;17920 pregnant women will be counselled and tested for HIV through PMTCT and 23,155,629 million condoms will be distributed by 2016.

iati-activity.title: Malawi Policing Improvement Programme
iati-activity.description: “To improve the capacity of the Malawi Police Service in enforcing internal accountability and managing public order by increasing the staff and resource capacity of the Internal Affairs Unit and training police officers at all levels in operational planning and human right compliant public order management. This will result in clearing 266 outstanding complaints against police officers and training at least 300 officers in public order management by July 2015 consequently reduces incidences of human rights abuse at the hands of the police and improve public satisfaction in police responsiveness and accountability.”

iati-activity.title: Malawi Rural Roads Improvement Programme
iati-activity.description: To upgrade 380 kms of rural unpaved roads in 5 districts of rural Malawi which will benefit up to 420,000 farming families in the districts of Karonga, Kasungu, Machinga, Phalombe and Nsanje. Improved transport will provide inhabitants of these districts with access to markets, health and other services. A total of 120kms of rural roads in the beneficiary districts will by 2015 be re-habilitated and upgraded while a further 260 kms of rural roads will be made passable all year-round by occassional spot improvements. The programme also expects by 2015 for (a) 10% of land to be planted to cash crops; (b) 10% improvement for women to access better health care and (c) 2.2 million days of work opportunities in improving roads.

iati-activity.title: Scaling Up Nutrition in Malawi
iati-activity.description: To treat and prevent under-nutrition and acute malnutrition amongst under five aged children in 15 districts in Malawi. This will benefit 12, 700 children with severe and acute malnutrition treated, 320 , 000 women and caregivers provided with nutritional counselling to help improve infant and young child feeding practices, training of 6, 090 community and health workers and 2 900 pregnant and lactating mothers reached with effective nutrition interventions. This contributes towards MDGs 1-6 and will result in increased uptake and adoption of intergrated Community Based Management of Acute Malnutrition by 2015.

iati-activity.title: Support to Development of the National Statistical System (NSS) in Malawi
iati-activity.description: Improve the coordination and production of statistics in Malawi and strengthen the National Statistical System by providing the National Statistics Office with £600,000 between July 2013 and June 2016 through the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. This will benefit the Government of Malawi by increasing the availability and quality of statistics that inform development planning. It will also enable development partners to coordinate their support to the National Statistics Office more efficiently. This contributes indirectly to our MDGs by increasing the quality of evidence to determine progress against key development goals.

iati-activity.title: Malawi Joint Donor Humanitarian Emergency Response Fund
iati-activity.description: To deliver humanitarian assistance to over 150,000 individuals over three years across a range of sectorial interventions including health, food, nutrition, water and sanitation and shelter which will save lives and reduce suffering of Malawians affected by disasters. This contributes towards MDGs 1, 4, 6 and 7 by providing ready to use funds to enable humanitarian agencies deliver timely and coordinated assessments and humanitarian response by December 2015.

iati-activity.title: Humanitarian Response to Food Insecurity in Malawi 2013/14
iati-activity.description: To save lives and reduce suffering of vulnerable people affected by food security in Malawi by providing food and cash. This contributes to Millennium Development Goal 1 by increasing food security which will result in reduced poverty by 2014
